nodes.documentation:
@notice The heart of the recurring transaction.
     1. Check if the caller is the current tx request
     2. Execute the transaction
     3. Schedule a new tx request
     4. Cleanup
nodes.name: executeTransaction

devdoc.author: Joseph Reed
devdoc.details: This contract's allows decentralized execution of on-chain recurring tasks. It requires three main components:     1. An external source for calling transactions at future time. This contract uses the Ethereum Alarm Clock (EAC)     2. A transaction scheduler with the Recurring Transaction scheduled     3. A funded delegated wallet with the transaction scheduler set as a delegate The owner sets a maximum cost that they are willing to spend on a given transaction execution in their preferred token. To calculate the cost a gas price oracle determines the current network price times the transaction gas cost. A new transaction will fail if the cost to schedule is too high. As long as the delegated wallet has enough funds, the recurring transactions will continue to execute.

params._EAC: The Ethereum Alarm Clock smart contract responsible for decentralized execution of future transactions.
params._scheduler: The delegate from which to pull transaction costs and execute transaction calls
params._wallet: The funding wallet, change address, and owner of the deployed recurring transactions

params._limits: The execution limits applied to each recurring transaction

params._priorityCaller: The address that receives the base reward

devdoc.title: Recurring Transaction Contract

methods.constructor: The constructor must force the master copy to be initialized to ensure the master copy can never be owned and/or self destructed using the destroy function.

destroy().notice: Cleans up and destroys the recurring transaction. Any leftover ether is sent to the wallet.

initialize(address,address,address).notice: Uses 'initialize()' instead of a constructor to make use of the clone         factory at https://github.com/optionality/clone-factory. In general, 'initialize()' should be         called directly following the recurring transaction deployment through the use of a factory.

setExecutionLimits(uint256[3]).notice: Sets the execution limits for when a future transaction can be claimed, called, or cancelled.

setPriorityCaller(address).notice: Sets the priority caller that receives the base reward when a transaction is called.
